verses.text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
verses.comment: This marks the beginning of Eliphaz's third speech. Like in previous cycles, his words reflect prevailing wisdom traditions.

verses.text: Can a man be of benefit to God? Can even a wise person help him?
verses.comment: Eliphaz questions whether human righteousness affects God, assuming God's transcendence. This sets the stage for discussing grace and human merit.

verses.text: Is it any pleasure to the Almighty if you are righteous? Or is it a gain to him if you make your ways blameless?
verses.comment: The text echoes the theme of divine sovereignty and humanity’s need for humility before God’s greatness.

verses.text: Is it because of your fear of him that he corrects you, or enters into judgment with you?
verses.comment: The language of correction links to the New Testament’s teaching on God's loving discipline of his children (Heb 12:6).

verses.text: Is not your wickedness great? Are not your iniquities without end?
verses.comment: Eliphaz accuses Job of great sin, reflecting the belief that suffering must result from unrighteousness. Later Scripture nuances the relationship between suffering and sin.

verses.text: For you have taken pledges from your brothers without cause, and stripped the naked of their clothing.
verses.comment: Accusations here reference social justice and the care for the poor prescribed in the Law (Ex 22:25–27).

verses.text: You have given no water to the weary to drink, and you have withheld bread from the hungry.
verses.comment: Compassion for the needy is a consistent Biblical theme, culminating in Christ's teaching that works of mercy are done unto Him (Matt. 25:35).

verses.text: But the powerful man, who owns the land, and the honored man, lives in it.
verses.comment: Eliphaz criticizes the exploitation of the weak by the strong, a theme continued throughout the prophets and the Gospel call to humility.

verses.text: You have sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherless have been crushed.
verses.comment: Caring for widows and orphans is both an Old and New Testament mark of true faith, with James later calling this 'pure religion' (James 1:27).

verses.text: Therefore snares are all around you, and sudden fear troubles you,
verses.comment: Eliphaz interprets Job’s suffering as divine retribution, but the reader knows from Job 1–2 that God's purposes are deeper than simple retributive justice.

verses.text: or darkness so that you cannot see, and an abundance of waters covers you.
verses.comment: The imagery of darkness and floods is frequent in the Psalms as a metaphor for affliction and spiritual trial.

verses.text: Is not God in the height of heaven? Look at the highest stars, how lofty they are!
verses.comment: Eliphaz highlights the transcendence and majesty of God; this awe is at the heart of Biblical worship.

verses.text: But you say, 'What does God know? Can he judge through deep darkness?'
verses.comment: 'Deep darkness' represents the human belief that God is far or cannot see, which Scripture elsewhere denies.

verses.text: Thick clouds cover him, so that he does not see; and he walks on the circle of the heavens.'
verses.comment: Again, Eliphaz describes God’s transcendence but is mistaken to imply God's knowledge can be obstructed.

verses.text: Will you keep to the old way that wicked men have trodden,
verses.comment: He urges Job not to follow the paths of the past evildoers, connecting righteousness with tradition.

verses.text: who were snatched away before their time, whose foundations were swept away by a flood?
verses.comment: Reference to the Flood in Genesis—a key biblical event where God judges sin but preserves a remnant.

verses.text: They said to God, 'Depart from us!' and 'What can the Almighty do to us?'
verses.comment: Echoes Job's earlier complaints about the apparent prosperity of the wicked.

verses.text: Yet he filled their houses with good things. But the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
verses.comment: Eliphaz admits God's providence even to the unworthy, a paradox that finds resolution in later teachings on divine mercy and providence.

verses.text: The righteous see it and are glad; the innocent mock them,
verses.comment: The theme that the just ultimately rejoice over vindication from evil.

verses.text: saying, 'Surely our adversaries are cut off, and fire has consumed what they left.'
verses.comment: Fire is a symbol of judgment throughout Scripture. Ultimately, Christ will judge (see Matt. 25:41).

verses.text: Submit to God and be at peace; in this way, good will come to you.
verses.comment: The concept of submission and reconciliation to God prefigures the call to conversion and peace in Christ (James 4:7).

verses.text: Receive instruction from his mouth, and lay up his words in your heart.
verses.comment: Storing God’s word in the heart points ahead to Christ’s teaching about keeping his commandments out of love (John 14:23).

verses.text: If you return to the Almighty, you will be restored—if you remove wickedness far from your tent,
verses.comment: Repentance and restoration are central here. The concept is developed through prophets and perfected in Christ’s ministry of reconciliation.

verses.text: and assign your gold to the dust, your precious gold of Ophir to the stones of the brooks,
verses.comment: True wealth is found in God, not material riches (see Matt. 6:19–21).

verses.text: then the Almighty will be your gold, and he will be your precious silver.
verses.comment: God himself is the believer's true wealth and desire (Ps. 73:25)—a foreshadowing of the beatific vision.

verses.text: For then you will delight yourself in the Almighty and lift up your face to God.
verses.comment: Joy and confidence come from intimate relationship with God, a theme fulfilled in union with Christ.

verses.text: You will pray to him, and he will hear you, and you will fulfill your vows.
verses.comment: Confidence in prayer foreshadows Christ’s promise to hear and answer the prayers of the faithful (John 14:13). Fulfilling vows points to the importance of sacramental commitment.

verses.text: What you decide on will be done for you, and light will shine on your ways.
verses.comment: God’s guidance and providence are promised to the righteous. 'Light' later becomes a symbol for Christ (John 8:12).

verses.text: When others are humbled and you say, 'Lift them up!' then he will save the lowly person.
verses.comment: God’s mercy to the humble is a theme throughout Scripture and central to Jesus’ teaching (see Matt. 23:12).

verses.text: He will deliver even the guilty one, who will be rescued because of the purity of your hands.
verses.comment: Here, the intercession of the righteous benefits others—a principle deepened in the New Testament and the Church’s tradition of prayer and mediation (see Gen. 18:23-32).
